qas.question: What was the percentsge of correction from the Julian calendar to the new Gregorian calendar?
What was the correction due to?
What change in date motivated the change in calendars?
To what astrological date was Easter tied?
What was wrong in the Julian calendar?
What percentage did the Julian calendar fixed the Gregorian calendar?
What was too short in the Julian calendar?
What did the spring equinox motivate the church to change?

plausible_answers.text: the steady drift in the date of Easter caused by the year being slightly too long

qas.question: What did the Protestant church considered to be undesirable?
What was first adopted by Eastern Orthodox countries

context: <b7_0><b9_0>The calendar<b9_0/><b7_0/> was a refinement to the Julian calendar amounting to a <a0_0><b5_0>0.002%<b5_0/><a0_0/> correction in <b6_0>the <a1_0>length of the year<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The motivation for the reform was to bring the date for the <a2_0>celebration of Easter<a2_0/> to the time of the year in which it was celebrated when it was introduced by the early Church. Because the celebration of Easter was tied to the <a3_0>spring equinox<a3_0/>, the Roman Catholic Church considered <b8_0>the steady drift in the date of Easter caused by the year being <a4_0>slightly too long<b8_0/><a4_0/> to be undesirable. The reform was adopted initially by the Catholic countries of Europe. Protestants and Eastern Orthodox countries continued to use the traditional Julian calendar and adopted the Gregorian reform after a time, for the sake of convenience in international trade. The last European country to adopt the reform was Greece, in 1923.
